channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Myanmar Coup Highlights Autocracy's Rise in Southeast Asia
item.description: Not long ago, democracy seemed to be surging in the region. But in Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and elsewhere, it is in trouble.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A protest this month in Yangon, Myanmar, against the military’s ouster of the civilian government.

item.title: Japan to Start Releasing Radioactive Water From Fukushima in 2 Years
item.description: The government says the plan is the best way to dispose of water used to prevent the ruined nuclear plant’s damaged reactor cores from melting.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Kota Endo/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Okuma, Japan. The government has decided to release radioactive water from the plant into the Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Britain Rejoices and Asks: Are Lockdowns Finally Finished?
item.description: Experience with the pandemic has taught Britons to be wary of setbacks, but as some pubs and stores reopened and the coronavirus abated, it was hard not to hope.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: People returning to Carnaby Street in London on Monday as retail shops reopened.

item.title: After Nuclear Site Blackout, Thunder From Iran, and Silence From U.S.
item.description: The Americans and Israelis have worked together in the past to impede Iran’s nuclear ambitions, but the U.S. denies that was the case in the latest sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, vowed revenge against Israel.

item.title: The Ghosts of Northern Ireland’s Troubles Are Back. What’s Going On?
item.description: A peace agreement nearly a quarter-century ago helped transform Northern Ireland after decades of bitter conflict. But new issues are reawakening old feuds.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Peter Robins
item.media:description: Police officers form a line on Springfield Road in Belfast to keep nationalist and loyalist groups from attacking each other on Wednesday.

item.title: French Wine Production Ravaged by a Devastating Frost
item.description: France’s winegrowers had already been hit by higher U.S. taxes and the pandemic. Now they are dealing with a “violent” cold snap.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: A winegrower, Pierre-Marie Luneau, checks the vine buds at a vineyard in Le Landreau, near Nantes, France, on Monday.

item.title: Peru Election for the 5th President in 5 Years Goes to Runoff
item.description: Pedro Castillo, a far-left former union activist and teacher, is leading, according to election officials.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:description: Pedro Castillo, a former union activist and teacher, was the surprise lead in an election characterized by widespread frustration with the political system.

item.title: From William and Harry, Loving but Separate Tributes to Prince Philip
item.description: The brothers paid homage to the Duke of Edinburgh’s service to the nation and to the Queen, but also shared personal memories of their grandfather.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Harry, left, and Prince William, right, with their grandfather, Prince Philip, at a rugby match in London in 2015.

item.title: Ready or Not, Hideki Matsuyama Is Now a National Hero in Japan
item.description: By winning the Masters, the publicity-shy golfer will face a news media spotlight that trails every move of Japanese athletes abroad.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Hideki Matsuyama won the Masters on Sunday, the first victory by a Japanese man in a major championship.

item.title: BTS Fans Mobilize to Denounce Anti-Asian Jokes Targeting the Boy Band
item.description: A global outcry fueled by a sketch on a Chilean comedy show reflected a growing sensitivity to racist, particularly anti-Asian, speech.
item.dc:creator: Russell Goldman
item.media:description: Members of BTS promoting their new album in Seoul in November.

item.title: ‘Tell Us if He’s Dead’: Abductions and Torture Rattle Uganda
item.description: Hundreds have been detained, many brutalized, after a bloody, contested election. The government of Yoweri Museveni appears intent on breaking the back of the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A climate of fear surrounds the headquarters of the leading opposition party in Kampala, Uganda’s capital.

item.title: The Iran Nuclear Talks, Explained
item.description: Talks in Vienna to try to bring both the United States and Iran back into compliance with the 2015 nuclear deal were never going to be easy. They might have just gotten even harder.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A mural in Tehran in May 2019, a year after President Donald J. Trump withdrew the United States from the deal limiting Iran’s nuclear activities.

item.title: Covid-19: Britain Begins to Reopen, Emerging From One of the World’s Longest Lockdowns
item.description: The C.D.C. director called for Michigan to shut down, rebuffing efforts by its governor to secure an extra supply of vaccine doses. New York is ending a requirement for international travelers to quarantine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Ecuador Elections: Guillermo Lasso Set to Win Presidential Vote
item.description: Guillermo Lasso was ahead of Andrés Arauz late Sunday night in an election that saw the emergence of the country’s long marginalized Indigenous movement as a key driver of the political conversation.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Johanna Alarcon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Kañari woman carrying food for her animals in Cuenca, Ecuador. Eight percent of Ecuadoreans identify as Indigenous, according to the census, but much of the electorate is of mixed background.

item.title: Could the Pandemic Prompt an ‘Epidemic of Loss’ of Women in the Sciences?
item.description: Even before the pandemic, many female scientists felt unsupported in their fields. Now, some are hitting a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alisa Stephens, a biostatistician at the University of Pennsylvania. Scientists of color not only routinely encounter biases in the workplace, but also have had to cope with the disproportionate impact of the pandemic on their communities.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: England eases out of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons returned outside at the Carlton Tavern in London on Monday after pandemic restrictions were eased.

item.title: Pentagon Chief Orders New Review of Attack in Kenya That Killed 3 Americans
item.description: The unusual review of the conclusions of the initial inquiry comes more than a year after the attack by the Shabab revealed security lapses at the base.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: U.S. Air Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: American troops at Manda Bay, Kenya, in 2019. Manda Bay had a reputation as a quiet and unchallenged locale before the brazen strike in January 2020.

item.title: Graduation ceremonies will be allowed in New York this spring, with restrictions.
item.description: The governor outlined how schools and colleges may hold commencement ceremonies in the coming months, with curtailed attendance tied to the capacity of venues.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: Eric Doulman taking a photo of his graduating daughter, Hannah, in front of photos of her graduating class outside James Madison High School in Brooklyn last May.

item.title: Two worrisome variants make up over 70 percent of cases analyzed in N.Y.C., city officials say.
item.description: The data represents the first time city officials have offered a ZIP-code level look at how the variants have been spreading in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:description: Waiting to ride the Staten Island Ferry in New York last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Britain starts to reopen.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: People drink in a pub in London on Monday.

item.title: Pennsylvania and L.A. Move Up Dates for Vaccine Eligibility
item.description: Pennsylvania and the city of Los Angeles each moved up the dates when all adult residents will qualify for a shot. All 50 states should reach that point by next Monday.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Emily Matthews/Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Allegheny Health Network hosted a vaccine clinic last week in Coraopolis, a suburb of Pittsburgh.

item.title: The C.D.C. director says Michigan needs to shut down, not get extra vaccine, to slow its virus outbreak.
item.description: The remarks rebuff efforts by Gov. Gretchen Whitmer to secure an extra supply of vaccine doses as Michigan is seeing a worst-in-the-nation surge of coronavirus infections.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Mitch Smith and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: People crowding for outdoor dining at a restaurant in Ann Arbor, Mich., last week.

item.title: Severe Covid Cases Surge in Gaza as Ramadan Nears
item.description: The coronavirus variant identified in Britain is proliferating in the Gaza Strip, where fewer than 1 percent of residents have been vaccinated so far.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: The positivity rate for Covid tests in Gaza has been running very high, a sign of rapid community spread. A health worker collected a nasal swab sample from a man in Gaza City on Monday.

item.title: NY Ends Requirement to Quarantine for International Travelers, But Recommends They Still Do So
item.description: The change was intended to bring the state in line with travel recommendations issued earlier this month by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:description: John F. Kennedy Airport in New York in January.

item.title: Over 50,000 N.Y.C. Public School Students Will Return to Classrooms
item.description: The change follows recent federal guidance that schools could reduce social distancing between students in some classrooms to three feet from six.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students lining up to enter Clara Barton High School in Crown Heights last month.

item.title: David Cameron Faces Inquiry Into His Dealings With Greensill
item.description: The British former prime minister has said that he did nothing illegal, but he has acknowledged mistakes in pleading Greensill Capital’s case with government ministers.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: “I accept that communications with government need to be done through only the most formal of channels,” David Cameron said in a statement on Sunday.

item.title: The Symbol of Bessemer
item.description: We look at Amazon’s victory over a labor union — and the meaning of $15-an-hour jobs.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Amazon’s fulfillment center in Bessemer occupies the site of a former steel mill.

item.title: England reopens shops and some pubs and restaurants after three months of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Decorating the exterior of an Italian restaurant in London on Sunday. Pubs and restaurants were permitted to reopen outdoor spaces on Monday.

item.title: In Iraq, Drought and Abundance in the Mesopotamian Marshes
item.description: Once vengefully drained by Saddam Hussein, the wetlands in southeastern Iraq have since been partially restored. Now the region and its isolated settlements face a new set of challenges.
item.dc:creator: Emilienne Malfatto
item.media:credit: Emilienne Malfatto for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman carries reeds on her boat in Iraq’s Central Marsh.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A snapshot of Europe’s lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An eating area in Covent Garden is decorated with plants before its reopening. Non-essential retail and hospitality can reopen in London starting today.

item.title: A Clash of Wills Keeps a Leonardo Masterpiece Hidden
item.description: The Louvre inspected the “Salvator Mundi” and certified it as the work of Leonardo da Vinci. But it kept those findings secret after a squabble with the painting’s owners.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick and Elaine Sciolino
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Salvator Mundi” sold for $450.3 million in 2017, shattering auction records. It has not been seen in public since.

item.title: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Big at Diverse BAFTAs
item.description: Four awards went to Chloé Zhao’s tale of itinerant Americans, living in vans and rolling through gorgeous landscapes, seeking temporary jobs to eke out an existence.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: Greg Abbott Speculates Texas Has Herd Immunity
item.description: When asked why his state wasn’t seeing higher reported cases after removing restrictions, the Texas governor speculated that the population had reached herd immunity.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waiting in line to enter a vaccination site at a high school in Houston last month.

item.title: Blinken Calls for More Thorough Investigation of Covid Origins in China
item.description: “We need to get to the bottom of this,” Antony J. Blinken said of the origins of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the State Department in Washington this month.

item.title: Myanmar Protests, and Killings, Continue
item.description: The death toll has passed 700, with more than 80 killed on Friday in one city alone, a rights group said.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: University students marching against the military coup in Yangon, Myanmar, on Sunday.

item.title: Need New Skills? How About a Hug? The Women’s Shed Welcomes You.
item.description: In Australia, men’s sheds became a global model for helping “old boys” continue living meaningful lives. Now, women are starting their own.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Michaela Skovranova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Learning new skills at the Playford Women's Shed in the northern suburbs of Adelaide, Australia.

item.title: Blackout Hits Iran Nuclear Site in What Appears to Be Israeli Sabotage
item.description: The power failure was described by Iran as “nuclear terrorism” as talks were underway in Vienna to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The Natanz nuclear facility in Iran lost power on Sunday. It houses centrifuges used for uranium enrichment.

item.title: China Official Acknowledges Low Effectiveness of the Country's Covid Vaccines
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A medical worker giving a vaccine in Beijing in January.

item.title: In Peru’s Presidential Election, the Most Popular Choice Is No One
item.description: Peruvians head to the polls at a moment that many are calling one of the lowest points in the country’s young democracy, and many plan to cast empty ballots.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:description: Eighteen presidential candidates were on the ballot in Peru. Campaign signs lined a street in Lima, the capital.

item.title: ‘Everything Is Worth Freedom’: Uganda’s Opposition Leader Faces the Future
item.description: Bobi Wine, the pop star who became a presidential candidate, considers rebuilding his anti-government movement after a violent election season that left many aides and supporters imprisoned.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader Bobi Wine at his home in Magere, a neighborhood in Uganda’s capital city, Kampala.

item.title: My Family’s Global Vaccine Journey
item.description: We were spread across three continents, at the mercy of vaccine geopolitics. Which of us would be inoculated last?
item.dc:creator: Pui-Wing Tam
item.media:credit: Thoko Chikondi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Pui-Ying Iroh Tam, right, outside makeshift Covid-19 wards at Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital in Blantyre, Malawi, this month.

item.title: After Snatching One Crown, Mrs. World Gives Up Her Own
item.description: Last year’s winner of a pageant for married women grabbed a crown from the 2021 Mrs. Sri Lanka winner, who she claimed was divorced, in violation of pageant rules.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.media:description: The reigning Mrs. World, Caroline Jurie, left, forcibly removed the crown of Mrs. Sri Lanka World winner, Pushpika de Silva, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last weekend.

item.title: New Hampshire and Oklahoma Move to Open Covid Vaccines to Nonresidents
item.description: The moves come as President Biden pushed up the deadline to make all adults eligible for a vaccine and as the pace of inoculations is accelerating in the country.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: Vehicles lined up at a mass vaccination site in Loudon, N.H., last month. New Hampshire is dropping its residency requirement for receiving the vaccine.

item.title: After Going ‘Free of L.G.B.T.,’ a Polish Town Pays a Price
item.description: Krasnik voted to be “free of L.G.B.T.” two years ago to satisfy conservative voters. Now, the mayor regrets the move, which has led to censure from other European countries and put funding at risk.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Kasia Strek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Krasnik has become central to a debate over traditional and modern values in Poland.

item.title: AstraZeneca Vaccine and Blood Clots: What Is Known So Far
item.description: In rare cases, an immune reaction has led to antibodies that caused a serious clotting disorder. But public health experts maintain the vaccine’s benefits far outweigh the risks for most people.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Denise Grady

item.title: Sliding in the Polls, Erdogan Kicks Up a New Storm Over the Bosporus
item.description: As part of a push to carve a canal alongside the waterway, Turkey’s president signaled that he could scrap a treaty that has kept peace in the region for decades.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ortakoy Mosque in Istanbul.

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Kills at Least 6 People
item.description: Television reports showed people running in panic from malls and buildings in several cities in East Java Province. The earthquake shook the tourist hot spot of Bali.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: A house damaged by the earthquake in East Java Province, Indonesia, on Saturday.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani, Afghanistan's President, Has Little Sway Over Its Future
item.description: Ashraf Ghani has few remaining allies, the Taliban are gaining militarily and his international supporters are impatient with him and the stumbling peace process.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan arriving for the opening ceremony of the new session of Parliament in Kabul last month.

item.title: A Soviet ‘Lord of the Rings’ Is Unearthed, Epic in Its Own Way
item.description: Tolkien fans received an unexpected gift with the rediscovery of an all-but-forgotten 1991 production. They were also left with questions, like “why is Gollum wearing a lettuce on his head?”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A screenshot from YouTube of the character Gollum as he appears in an adaptation of J.R.R. Tolkien’s “The Lord of the Rings” that was broadcast on Russian television in 1991.

item.title: ‘You Can’t Trust Anyone’: Russia’s Hidden Covid Toll Is an Open Secret
item.description: The country’s official coronavirus death toll is 102,649. But at least 300,000 more people died last year during the pandemic than were reported in Russia’s most widely cited official statistics.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graves from 2020 and 2021 at the Rubezhnoye cemetry on the outskirts of Samara, Russia.

item.title: Harry Will Attend Philip’s Funeral, Raising Hope Royal Rift Will Heal
item.description: Although Harry will come home to mourn with the family, his pregnant wife Meghan will not. The patriarch’s death opens an uncertain chapter for the House of Windsor.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Philip with, from left, Prince William; Kate, Duchess of Cambridge; Meghan, Duchess of Sussex; and Prince Harry on Christmas Day in 2017.

item.title: Royal Rivalry Bares Social Tensions Behind Jordan’s Stable Veneer
item.description: The standoff between King Abdullah II and his half brother, Prince Hamzah, wasn’t just palace intrigue. It hinted at Saudi meddling and highlighted wider tensions within Jordan’s complex society.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Rana F. Sweis and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Hamzah bin Hussein, Prince of Jordan
item.media:description: A poster of King Abdullah II of Jordan on a street in Amman on Wednesday.

item.title: Turkey Fights for Return of a Work It Says Was Looted
item.description: A bench trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan concerns an ancient idol held by Christie’s.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: An image of what is known as “The Guennol Stargazer,” from a legal document in the lawsuit against Christie’s.

item.title: For Prince Philip, Royal Family Plans Pandemic-Muted Honors
item.description: Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will not lie in state for public viewing and the funeral will not be open to the public, in a nod to a ban on mass gatherings and the prince’s own wishes.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Marc Santora
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crowd gathered outside Buckingham Palace in London on Friday.

item.title: A Bleak Forecast for Canada’s 600,000 Energy Industry Workers
item.description: A report forecasts that up to three quarters of their jobs may vanish in a low carbon future and suggests a better approach to retraining.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Alec Jacobson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crew closing a well in Alliance, Alberta.

item.title: Russian Troop Movements and Talk of Intervention Cause Jitters in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has amassed more troops on the Ukrainian border than at any time since 2014. Western governments are asking: Why now?
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the front lines facing Russian-backed separatists near the town of Zolote this month.

item.title: Pfizer Requests Authorization to Use Vaccine in Young Teens
item.description: If the emergency use authorization is broadened, young adolescents could start getting vaccinated before going back to school in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: A teenager receives a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in New York on Tuesday. The companies asked to expand their vaccine’s emergency use authorization to include adolescents ages 12 to 15.

item.title: Blood Clots Linked to AZ Vaccine Stem From Rare Antibody Reaction
item.description: New studies from Germany and Norway examined cases involving mostly younger people who developed serious and sometimes fatal blood disorders.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: A dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine being administered in Bucharest, Romania, in February. The vaccine has been a mainstay of inoculation programs in more than 100 countries.

item.title: Netflix's ‘The Crown’ Changed Prince Philip’s Image
item.description: The Netflix show exposed a new generation to the prince’s life and helped reshape those already familiar with his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
